Without writing a little SQL parser/syntax checker, I'm not sure what to do=
. I wouldn't want to be the one to do it.

>So said Jeff Nielsen on 2003-07=
-20 --------------------
>I'd be interested in people's thoughts on the eas=
iest/best way to do
>this.  Basically, we have a bunch of JUnit tests that =
check SQL
>"SELECT" statements that are generated by a framework.  
>
>Thes=
e tests are currently a little painful to maintain, because if you
>modify =
the framework so that the order of the tables, columns, or where
>clause st=
atements changes somehow, every test has to change.  That got
>me wondering=
 about how to do an 
>
>  assertSemanticEquals(expectedSQL, actualSQL)
>
>w=
here the order of things within each brance of the select is
>irrelevant.  =
For example,
>
>  select foo.col1, bar.col2
>      from bar, foo 
>      wh=
ere bar.id =3D foo.id and bar.id > 4
>      order by bar.col2
>
>is semanti=
cally equivalent to
>
>  select bar.col2, foo.col1
>      from foo, bar 
> =
     where bar.id > 4 and foo.id =3D bar.id
>      order by bar.col2
>
>
>-=
